summary: Winston Scott was the Chief of Station for the CIA in Mexico during a period that is relevant to the JFK assassination. A memorandum details a conversation between President Lopez Mateos of Mexico and Mr. Winston Scott, Chief of Station, Mexico. He is mentioned in connection to the CIA station in Mexico City during Lee Harvey Oswald's visit, as gleaned from David Phillips' testimony and Boris Tarasoff's interviews. Robert T. Shaw's testimony before the HSCA also focuses on CIA activities in Mexico City in 1963 related to Lee Harvey Oswald and Cuban operations.
significance: Winston Scott's significance in the JFK context stems from his role as the CIA Chief of Station in Mexico City during the time Lee Harvey Oswald visited. His position places him as a key figure in understanding any potential CIA involvement or knowledge related to Oswald's activities in Mexico, particularly concerning Cuban operations. The documents suggest that his actions and the activities of the CIA station under his leadership were scrutinized in connection to the assassination.
